case_name: James Anderson v. Income Tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 335 of 1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 335 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated August 25, 1954 in Income-tax Reference No. 1 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 25, 1954, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 1 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by K. DAS, J. on March 4, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. March, 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-This appeal by special leave is from the decision of the Bombay High Court dated August 25, 1954, in Income-tax Reference No. 1 of 1954.

facts.text: Henry Gannon was a resident of British India assessed to income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The facts relevant to the appeal are these one Henry Gannon was a resident of British India, who used to be assessed to income-tax under the Income-tax law of this companyntry.

facts.text: Henry Gannon left India in 1944 for the United Kingdom.

anchor.surface_text: He left India in 1944 for the United Kingdom where he died on May 13, 1945.

facts.text: Henry Gannon died on May 13, 1945 in the United Kingdom.

anchor.surface_text: He left India in 1944 for the United Kingdom where he died on May 13, 1945.

facts.text: Henry Gannon left a will dated November 18, 1942 appointing National Bank of India Ltd., London as Executor.

anchor.surface_text: He left a will dated November 18, 1942 by which the National Bank of India Ltd., in London was appointed Executor of his estate.

facts.text: Probate of the will granted to National Bank of India Ltd. on October 1, 1945 by UK court.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1945, probate of the will was granted to the said Bank by a Court of companypetent jurisdiction in the United Kingdom.

facts.text: National Bank gave power of attorney to James Anderson (appellant) on October 25, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: On October 25, 1945, a power of attorney was given by the Bank to James Anderson, who is number the appellant before us.

facts.text: James Anderson obtained Letters of Administration with copy of will from Bombay High Court under s.241 Indian Succession Act.

anchor.surface_text: He made an application to the High Court of Bombay under s. 241 of the, Indian Succession Act and on that application obtained Letters of Administration with a companyy of the will annexed.

facts.text: Appellant sold shares and securities of Henry Gannon's estate to distribute assets to legatees.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of administration of the estate of Henry Gannon, the appellant sold certain shares and securities belonging to the deceased for the purpose of distributing the assets amongst the legatees.

facts.text: Sale of shares and securities realized more than cost price.

anchor.surface_text: The sale of these shares and securities realised more than their companyt price.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer treated excess sale price over cost as capital gain under s.12B.

anchor.surface_text: The excess of the sale price over the companyt price was treated by the Income Tax Officer as capital gain under s. 12B of the Income Tax Act.

facts.text: Capital gain for 1947-48 assessed at Rs. 20,13,738.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1947-48 the capital gain was companyputed by the Income Tax Officer at Rs. 20,13,738 and for the assessment year 1948-49 at Rs. 1,51,963.

facts.text: Capital gain for 1948-49 assessed at Rs. 1,51,963.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1947-48 the capital gain was companyputed by the Income Tax Officer at Rs. 20,13,738 and for the assessment year 1948-49 at Rs. 1,51,963.

facts.text: Capital gains taxed for 1947-48 and 1948-49 along with dividend and interest income.

anchor.surface_text: These amounts of capital gain were brought to tax for the assessment year 1947-48 and 1948-49 along with certain dividend and interest income which had accrued or had been received in the relevant years of account.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeals to Appellate Tribunal Bombay, which were consolidated.

anchor.surface_text: Not satisfied with these assessments, the appellant preferred two appeals to the Appellate Tribunal, Bombay. These two appeals were companysolidated.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal accepted third contention on third proviso to s.12B and allowed appeals in part, directing deletion of capital gains.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal repelled the first two companytentions, but accepted the third as companyrect and in that view allowed the two appeals in part. It directed the Income Tax Officer to delete from the assessed income the capital gains made by the sale of shares and securities.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax moved Appellate Tribunal to refer question on third proviso to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City, then moved the Appellate Tribunal to refer to the High Court of Bombay the question which arose out of the third companytention, namely, the true scope and effect of the third proviso to old s. 12B 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal referred question: Whether sale by administrator not a sale u/s 12B(1) in view of third proviso.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal thereupon referred the following question of law to the Bombay High Court Whether the sale of the shares and securities by the administrator of the estate of late Mr. Gannon is number a sale for the purpose of Section 12B 1  in view of the third proviso to section 12B 1  of the Indian Income Tax Act.

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered all three questions against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Bombay companysidered all the three questions in Income-tax Reference No. 1 of 1954 and by its decision appealed from answered all the three questions against the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on October 7, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved this Court for special leave which was granted on October 7, 1955.

facts.text: Capital gains charged first by Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1947 inserting s.12B, taxing gains after March 31, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Capital gains were charged for the first time by the Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax  Amendment  Act, 1947, which inserted s. 12B in the Act. It taxed capital gains arising after March 31, 1946.

facts.text: Levy abolished by Indian Finance Act, 1949 for gains before April 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The levy was virtually abolished by the Indian  1  1954 26 I.T.R. 758 1955 I. S.C.R. 829. Finance Act, 1949, which companyfined the operation of the section to capital gains arising before April 1, 1948

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal thereupon referred the following question of law to the Bombay High Court Whether the sale of the shares and securities by the administrator of the estate of late Mr. Gannon is number a sale for the purpose of Section 12B (1) in view of the third proviso to section 12B (1) of the Indian Income Tax Act.

issues.text: The only question which falls for decision in the appeal is the true scope and effect of the third proviso to old S. 12B (1) of the Indian Income Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The only question which falls for decision in the appeal is the true scope and effect of the third proviso to old S. 12B 1  of the Indian Income Tax Act, hereinafter referred to as the Act. The facts relevant to the appeal are these one Henry Gannon was a resident of British India, who used to be assessed to income-tax under the Income-tax law of this companyntry.

issues.text: We are, therefore, left only with the question which turns on the true scope and effect of the third proviso to old s. 12B (1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The question under s. 24B was also number seriously pressed. The view of the Bombay High Court that s. 24B does number limit the liability of the Administrator or Executor to the cases referred to under that section is companyrect because the appellant is as much an assessee under the Act as any other individual and if he makes capital gains, he is as much liable to pay tax as any other individual.

issues.text: what bearing the third proviso to sub-s. (1) has on the aforesaid scheme

anchor.surface_text: This in effect is the scheme of the three sub-sections. Manifestly, the intention of the legislature is to tax the profits made by the sale, exchange or transfer of capital assets and the incidence of the taxation falls at the time of the transfer. If the sale is made by the administrator or executor, the liability under sub-s. 1  falls on him if, however, the sale is made by a person who got the capital assets inter alia in any of the ways mentioned in sub-s. 3 , he becomes liable to tax as and when he sells the capital assets and makes profits therefrom. Now, the question is what bearing the third proviso to sub-s. 1  has on the aforesaid scheme.

issues.text: whether there has been a distribution of capital assets by the appellant under a will so as to bring him within the ambit of the third proviso

anchor.surface_text: In the present case we are companycerned with the question whether there has been a distribution of capital assets by the appellant under a will so as to bring him within the ambit of the third proviso. If the appellant companyes within that ambit, then the sales which he made of the shares and securities will number be treated as transfer within the meaning of sub-s. 1 .

issues.text: whether the expression 'distribution of capital assets' in the third proviso means distribution in specie or distribution of sale proceeds

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that the expression distribution of capital assets in the third proviso can only mean such distribution in specie it cannot and does number mean distribution of the sale proceeds of the capital assets. The High Court, therefore, held that the appellant did number companye within the protection of the third proviso, as he did number distribute the capital assets in specie.

issues.text: whether the third proviso contemplated involuntary transfers

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court an alternative argument was also presented on behalf of the assessee to the effect that the third proviso companytemplated involuntary transfers. This argument was based on the use of the expression by reason of in the proviso, and the proviso was sought to be read as follows  omitting words number relevant to the case  Provided further that any transfer of capital assets by reason of any distribution of capital assets under a will shall number for the purposes of this section be treated as sale, exchange or transfer of the capital assets.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the Bombay High Court that s. 24B does not limit the liability of the Administrator or Executor to the cases referred to under that section is correct because the appellant is as much an assessee under the Act as any other individual

holdings.text: The question whether the levy of capital gains under section 12B is ultra vires no longer survives by reason of the decision of this Court in Navinchandra Mafatlal v. Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the levy of capital gains under section 12B is ultra vires no longer survives by reason of the decision of this Court in Navinchandra Mafatlal v. Commissioner of Income-tax. This question was not therefore pressed before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Binding precedent from this Court settles the issue; not pressed by appellant.

holdings.text: s. 24B does not limit the liability of the Administrator or Executor to the cases referred to under that section; the appellant is an assessee under the Act liable to pay tax on capital gains made.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the Bombay High Court that s. 24B does not limit the liability of the Administrator or Executor to the cases referred to under that section is correct because the appellant is as much an assessee under the Act as any other individual and if he makes capital gains, he is as much liable to pay tax as any other individual.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Administrator treated as assessee in own right; liable for gains from sales during administration.

holdings.text: The scheme of sub-ss. (1), (2) and (3) of s. 12B taxes profits from sale, exchange or transfer of capital assets at the time of transfer by the person effecting it.

anchor.surface_text: This in effect is the scheme of the three sub-sections. Manifestly, the intention of the legislature is to tax the profits made by the sale, exchange or transfer of capital assets and the incidence of the taxation falls at the time of the transfer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of sub-sections shows tax incidence at transfer; distinguishes administrator sale from legatee sale.

holdings.text: The expression 'distribution of capital assets' in the third proviso to s. 12B(1) means distribution in specie and not distribution of sale proceeds; sale by administrator prior to distribution is a taxable transfer.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the view that the High Court rightly held that the expression distribution of capital assets in the third proviso to sub-s. (1) of s. 12B of the Act means distribution in specie and not distribution of sale proceeds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain meaning distinguishes capital assets from proceeds; proviso protects in specie distribution to fit scheme; avoids anomaly where admin escapes but legatee taxed.

holdings.text: The third proviso does not contemplate involuntary transfers for distributions under will; 'by reason of' attaches only to compulsory acquisition; voluntariness irrelevant to s.12B.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled this argument and for good reasons. Firstly, the question whether the sale was voluntary or involuntary is not germane to the scheme of section 12B. Secondly, on a proper reading of the proviso, the expression by reason of goes with the clause relating to compulsory acquisition of property and not with the distribution of capital assets.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading limits 'by reason of' to acquisition clause; scheme taxes all transfers regardless of voluntariness.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court decision upheld; third proviso to s. 12B(1) interpreted as distribution in specie only, not sale proceeds; sale by administrator is transfer taxable as capital gains under s. 12B

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the levy of capital gains under section 12B is ultra vires no longer survives by reason of the decision of this Court in Navinchandra Mafatlal v. Commissioner of Income-tax. This question was not therefore pressed before us.

We are accordingly of the view that the High Court rightly held that the expression distribution of capital assets in the third proviso to sub-s. 1  of s. 12B of the Act means distribution in specie and number distribution of sale proceeds. In the High Court an alternative argument was also presented on behalf of the assessee to the effect that the third proviso contemplated involuntary transfers.

anchor.surface_text: This in effect is the scheme of the three sub-sections. Manifestly, the intention of the legislature is to tax the profits made by the sale, exchange or transfer of capital assets and the incidence of the taxation falls at the time of the transfer.

We are accordingly of the view that the High Court rightly held that the expression distribution of capital assets in the third proviso to sub-s. 1  of s. 12B of the Act means distribution in specie and number distribution of sale proceeds. In the High Court an alternative argument was also presented on behalf of the assessee to the effect that the third proviso contemplated involuntary transfers.

edges.explanation: The holding interprets 'distribution of capital assets' in the third proviso to s.12B(1) and distinguishes sale by administrator prior to distribution, directly addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the view that the High Court rightly held that the expression distribution of capital assets in the third proviso to sub-s. (1) of s. 12B of the Act means distribution in specie and not distribution of sale proceeds.

We are accordingly of the view that the High Court rightly held that the expression distribution of capital assets in the third proviso to sub-s. 1  of s. 12B of the Act means distribution in specie and number distribution of sale proceeds. In the High Court an alternative argument was also presented on behalf of the assessee to the effect that the third proviso contemplated involuntary transfers.

The High Court repelled this argument and for good reasons. Firstly, the question whether the sale was voluntary or involuntary is not germane to the scheme of section 12B. Secondly, on a proper reading of the proviso, the expression by reason of goes with the clause relating to compulsory acquisition of property and not with the distribution of capital assets.

We are accordingly of the view that the High Court rightly held that the expression distribution of capital assets in the third proviso to sub-s. 1  of s. 12B of the Act means distribution in specie and number distribution of sale proceeds. In the High Court an alternative argument was also presented on behalf of the assessee to the effect that the third proviso contemplated involuntary transfers.
